OPELOUSAS RAILROAD CONVENTION.
New Orleans, Friday, January 2, 1852.
The Delegates to the Convention met at the Lyceum
Hall at 11 o'clock, a. m, for the transaction of business.
Col. Maunsel White, the President of the Convention,
on taking the chair, made the following address:
Gentlemen . I most heartily greet and welcome you here. The object of
@m meeting yon are felly acquainted with. The reports of the different committees, the surveys, estimates aud charts of the different routes, so far as we
have been able to obtain them, will he laid before you. It is not my intention
to offer you any outline, as you will receive all necessary information from the
documents themselves. The gentlemen charged with the preliminary business
lirrve been indefatigable in the performance of their duties, as you will
presently perceive.
I beg leave respectfully to recommend to you unity of action, a nrni, perse
wring energy hi the prosecution of whatever, after due deliberation, you may
determine upon. ,
I believe wc arc most of us practical, business men, who have come lime
with a definite purpose in view, the result of which may hereafter tell on tne
fortunes and prosperity of millions. . . ,
Would we be successful in carrying out our great design m obtammg tne
barter and adequate means of this great road, which is one day or ouiei to
unite the Atlantic and Pacific iu bands of iron, we must act. Acts five, an
